bestBHT.bht: It is plain to all that our Lord hath arisen. This is the only place in Scripture where Christ is called by this appellation without the addition of either His personal or official name. It is evident that our Lord sprung as a branch out of the root of Jesse, and is of the tribe of Judah. Whatever difficulties have arisen since, during so long a tract of time, it was then clear beyond dispute.

Henry Alford: For it is plain to all that our Lord hath arisen."
This is the only place in Scripture where Christ is called by this appellation, now so familiar to us, without the addition of either His personal or official name."
Nothing to imply that any priests should be or be consecrated out of it: reserving that entirely for the tribe of Levi.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: evident—literally, 'manifest before the eyes' as a thing indisputable; a proof that whatever difficulties may now appear, then Jesus Christ's genealogy labored under none.
our Lord—the only place where this now common title occurs without 'Jesus,' or 'Christ.'
sprang—as a plant, and a branch.
Albert Barnes: For it is evident that our Lord sprang out of Judah - It is well known: it cannot be a matter of dispute.
About the fact that the Lord Jesus was of the tribe of Judah, there could be no doubt.
The fact that the Messiah is to be of the tribe of Judah is still admitted by the Jews.
Marvin Vincent: In N. T. always of the rising of a heavenly body, sun or star, except Luke 12:54, of a cloud, and here.
Philip Schaff: For it is evident that our Lord hath sprung as a branch out of the root of Jesse."
Christ is said to ‘spring up’ in both senses [as a branch out of the root or as the sun or the star rises]."
This is the only place in Scripture where this name ‘Our Lord,’ now so familiar, is applied to Christ without the addition of His proper name Jesus, or His official name Christ.
Archibald T. Robertson: It is evident (προδηλον). Old compound adjective (προ, δηλος), openly manifest to all, in N.T. only here and 1 Timothy 5:24.
Hath sprung (ανατεταλκεν). Perfect active indicative of ανατελλω, old compound to rise up like the sun (Matthew 5:45).
John Gill: It is certain that the Messiah was to spring from that tribe, Genesis 49:10.
It is evident that Jesus, who is our Lord by creation, redemption, and the conquest of his grace, sprung from this tribe.

He said many things of it in Deuteronomy 33:8 and relates many things concerning it as spoken by Jacob, but nothing about the priesthood, as if it belonged to that, or that any that should spring from it should exercise that office.
John Wesley: For it is evident that our Lord sprang out of Judah.
Whatever difficulties have arisen since, during so long a tract of time, it was then clear beyond dispute.

bhtAttempts.bht: It is plain to all that our Lord hath arisen. This is the only place in Scripture where Christ is called by this appellation without the addition of either His personal or official name. It is evident that our Lord sprung as a branch out of the root of Jesse, and is of the tribe of Judah. About the fact that the Lord Jesus was of the tribe of Judah, there could be no doubt. It is certain that the Messiah was to spring from that tribe. Whatever difficulties have arisen since, during so long a tract of time, it was then clear beyond dispute.

It is plain to all that our Lord hath arisen. This is the only place in Scripture where Christ is called by this appellation without the addition of either His personal or official name. It is evident that our Lord sprung as a branch out of the root of Jesse, and is of the tribe of Judah. Whatever difficulties have arisen since, during so long a tract of time, it was then clear beyond dispute.

It is evident that our Lord, without the addition of His personal or official name, has risen. This verse in Hebrews is the only place where Christ is called by this appellation alone. There is nothing to suggest that any priests should come from any other tribe besides Levi. The fact that Jesus Christ is from the tribe of Judah is indisputable, just as a plant springs up as a branch. It is clear beyond dispute that our Lord has arisen and is the fulfillment of the prophecy that the Messiah would come from the tribe of Judah.

Our Lord has unquestionably risen without the need for any additional names. In Hebrews, there is a unique reference to Christ, using only the appellation of 'our Lord.' This verse makes it clear that the priesthood is reserved solely for the tribe of Levi and not open to any others. The birthright of Jesus Christ as a descendant of Judah is undeniable, as He has sprung forth like a branch. The fact that our Lord arises from the tribe of Judah is an indisputable truth and a fulfillment of ancient prophecies.

It is plain to all that our Lord has arisen, recognizable by the appellation 'our Lord' in this unique context. The tribe of Levi is exclusively designated for priests, while Jesus Christ's genealogy is free from any such limitations. Clearly, Jesus, as a branch, has sprung forth from the tribe of Judah. This fact is evident and beyond dispute, fulfilling the prophecy that the Messiah would come from this tribe.
